CONCLUSION: Net-net - SPV's rock for a ton of things:
(1) solve over concentration
(2) Invest outside of fund thesis 
(3) to help a new manager build track record 

BUT - make sure you're backing an SPV managed by a firm that has done it before and is stable

1059587956510543873.text: 7/ You're reporting won't be great. If your manager is doing a lot of SPV's, they all have diff reporting at diff intervals with low consistency and it's hard to manage

1059587619909222400.text: 6/ Your manager's operations will be under-funded. SPV's don't come with traditional management fees, meaning the manager can't used guaranteed rev to hire junior staff to manage/report investments. You will have an under-funded/stretched too thin manager

1059587342061760513.text: 4/ Your manager will have trouble making follow on investments. She will have to re-raise from investors at each round. Your co-investors in the SPV may not re-up, either leaving the company stranded or not giving your manager enough leverage/enough of a check book

1059587175497547776.text: 3/ Allocations are a pain. If you invest in an SPV you will either get crammed down, or asked to do more at the last minute. Allocations are an impossible jig-saw puzzle with too many/too few pieces.

1059586918462210048.text: 2/ SPV's don't invest on contrarian ideas. Managers have to raise money on the IDEA, when it comes to an SPV. Meaning a lot of people have to agree on the idea... meaning it's not contrarian (usually already priced in)

1059586703609024512.text: 1/ The manager you are backing is spending more of her time fundraising than she is doing diligence, deal execution, and monitoring. Someone running an SPV is as much a FUNDRAISER as they are an INVESTOR.

1059586538525417472.text:
